description: For set families with |Aᵢ| > c√n and pairwise |Aᵢ ∩ Aⱼ| ≤ 1, must a blocker exist with O(1) intersection? DISPROVED by Alon using projective plane constructions.

overview.historicalContext:
**Erdős Problem #664 (Blocking Sets with Bounded Intersection)**

**Origin:**
Erdős posed this problem in [Er81] (1981), asking whether near-linear set families (large sets with small pairwise intersection) always admit 'nice' blocking sets that intersect each set in O(1) points.

**Motivation:**
This relates to blocking sets in finite geometries: can we find a blocking set (meeting every line) that doesn't concentrate on any single line?

**Resolution:**
Nils Alon disproved the conjecture using a probabilistic construction based on projective planes. For n = q² + q + 1, random subsets of projective plane lines give families where any blocker must have logarithmically large intersection with some set.
overview.problemStatement:
**Problem Statement (Disproved)**

Let c < 1 and A₁,...,Aₘ ⊆ {1,...,n} with |Aᵢ| > c√n and |Aᵢ ∩ Aⱼ| ≤ 1 for i ≠ j.

Must there exist B such that B ∩ Aᵢ ≠ ∅ and |B ∩ Aᵢ| = O_c(1) for all i?

**Answer: NO**

**Alon's Counterexample:**
For n = m = q² + q + 1 (q large prime), random subsets of projective plane lines give:
- |Aᵢ| ≥ (2/5)√n
- |Aᵢ ∩ Aⱼ| ≤ 1
- Any blocker has |B ∩ Aⱼ| ≥ Ω(log n) for some j

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #664 asked whether near-linear set families (|Aᵢ| > c√n, pairwise intersection ≤ 1) always admit blocking sets with O(1) intersection. Alon disproved this using projective plane constructions: for n = q² + q + 1, any blocker must have Ω(log n) intersection with some set. The original balanced block design version remains open.
